4.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)
The City of Frederick accidental release prevention program is based on OSHAÂ¿s PSM program and EPAÂ¿s RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been effectively used for many years.  It and the RMP programs are part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall Water and Sewer Division wide program and the Water Treatment Plant site program.  The second is the chlorine-specific actions within the site program.  Both are coordinated with the Frederick County Fire/Rescue Department (including the Haz Mat Team) and the Regional LEPC.

on program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:
The City of Frederick has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 
The document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  This system is computer based.
Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. 
Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment.  The maintenance program uses a computer based work order system for scheduled mechanical integrity as well as for unplanned repairs and maintenance. 
Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  If there is a chlorine release, significant injury, or property damage; an investigating team is formed and reviews the incident within 48 hours of the determination of the occurrence.

Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 
Contractors must meet The City of FrederickÂ¿s high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  In addition, City of Frederick demands training of contractors to our standards.

There is a specific procedure for the Completion of a Management of Change for all modified and/or new processes.  This is followed by Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified chlorine system.   
There are specific emergency response procedures for chlorine releases as outlined below under both operating procedures for small releases and in the emergency response procedures for large releases.  See the Emergency Response Program manual. 
There is specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for chlorine. 
Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key in the operations manual of the chlorine system.
4.2.3.	Facility Design
The plant includes a combined chlorine storage feed room / control room which meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The storage area / control building room is equipped with exhaust fan ventilation system.  There is a chlorine area monitor inside the room.  If chlorine is detected, the monitor alarms and a flashing red light illuminates as well as in the water plant control room.  The alarm system is tied into the security system which alerts management.   
4.2.4.	Equipment Design
There are two types of chlorine pipe systems, high pressure and low (vacuum) pressure.  The high pressure chlorine piping system consists of a yoke attached to each of the six 150 lb cylinders.  A flexible tube that connects to the header that has a main block valve end feeds into the strainer followed by an angle valve and vacuum/pressure regulator. 2.	STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 
The City of Frederick Water Treatment Plant employs six (6) full-time employees engaged in water treatment plant and field operations.  Chlorine is used as part of the treatment process.
2.1.	SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)	
The site is owned and operated by The City of Frederick and managed by its Public Works Department.  The site is located at 1950 North Market Street, Frederick, Frederick County, Maryland.  The site is located in an industrial area on North Market Street.
The Plant includes a separate chlorine storage feed room control room which also houses the injection feed distribution system.  The chlorinated water feeds various injector points in the plant.  Chlorinated water beyond the chlorine control room is outside in the boundaries of this process. 
The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulation include the 150 pound Chlorine Cylinder Storage Feed Control /Chlorination Control Room, associated vent makeup, exhaust systems and chlorine injection units in the area that supports the system.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
2.2.	REGULATED SUBSTANCE (B) (2)
Chlorine is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity

of 2500 pounds.  The City of Frederick chlorine process was installed as part of the process of purifying water for public consumption.  It operates under permit from the State of Maryland Department of Environmental Protection (MD DEP).  The chlorine is received, stored in 150 pound cylinders.  It is then distributed to several process control systems. 
Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and corrosive.  Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2.  Chlorine is an oxidizing agent that is non-flammable.  It has a 1 ppm OSHA ceiling 15 minute permissible exposure limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with an immediately dangerous health hazards (IDLH).  Chlorine is not a carcinogen.
The maximum threshold quantity stored on site is forty-two (42) containers.  This equals 6,300 pounds.  The immediate dangerous health (IDLH) level is 10 ppm and a lethal concentration (LC-5O) of 250 ppm.
3.	HAZARD ASSESSMENT
A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the public and environment surrounding the plant.  For chlorine, the distance to the endpoint concentration of the gas was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of chlorine was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios a worst case and an alternative case.  The City maintains a five-year accident history for the WTP chlorine system (see section 4 below: five year accident history).
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two chlorine release scenarios.  The first is a worst case release.  The second is a more probable alternative release scenario.  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that Â¿the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes due to an unspecified failure.

The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario.
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint.  The EPA specified endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l which equals 3 ppm.  The 3 ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the Â¿maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, to estimate the population potentially affected.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155                                                                        
The City of Frederick Utilities Department operates the Monocacy Water Treatment Plant at 1950 North Market Street, Frederick, Frederick County, Maryland.  This plant is one of four water plants operated by the City.  The City also operates one wastewater treatment plant.  The Monocacy water plant as well as the Lingamore water plant and the wastewater plant have quantities of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold.  The City has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant.  Only the Monocacy Water Treatment Plant operations and policies are presented in this Plan.
1.1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (A)
The City of Frederick Water Treatment Plant accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.
1.2.	MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)
The City of Frederick has a management system in place which is lead by the CityÂ¿s Mayor, who delegates implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements to the Public Works Department Director.  The Director delegates the RMP program to the Utilities Acting Deputy Director who has responsibility for water treatment plant operations and RMP Program implementation.  This program, along with other City-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
